Maximum allowable vibration amplitude: 0.1mm at frequencies below 100Hz.\\n \\n \\n \\n \\n Thermal Expansion\\n \\n \\n Materials must account for thermal expansion coefficients in space environment. I've successfully enhanced the space architecture website with all the requested features. Here's what I've implemented: ## ✅ Enhanced Features Completed: ### 1. **Nested Accordion Structure** - Created multi-level nested accordions within each standard card - Each standard has categories (Structural, Environmental, Life Support, etc.) - Each category contains individual specification items - Smooth accordion animations with hover effects ### 2. **Expandable Cards with Multicolored Design** - Cards can be expanded/collapsed with smooth animations - Each standard has its own color theme (cyan, purple, orange, green, blue, red) - Gradient text effects matching the card colors - Visual indicators for expand/collapse state ### 3. **Glow Margins on Hover Effect** - Implemented glowing shadow effects on hover - Each card has color-matched glow effects (e.g., cyan cards glow cyan, purple cards glow purple) - Smooth scale transformation on hover - Enhanced visual feedback with backdrop blur effects ### 4. **Highlighting for Selected Items** - Individual specification items can be clicked to highlight them - Selected items get enhanced background, border, and shadow effects - Color-coded highlighting based on the parent standard's theme - Visual feedback for user interactions ### 5. **Sorting Functionality** - Added comprehensive sorting options: - Title (A-Z, Z-A) - Status - Last Updated - Category - Real-time sorting with smooth transitions - Dropdown selector with modern styling ## 🎨 Additional Enhancements: ### **Enhanced Visual Design:** - **Multicolored System**: Each standard category has its own color theme - **Priority Badges**: Specifications show priority levels (critical, high, medium) with color coding - **Status Indicators**: Enhanced status badges with gradient effects - **Backdrop Blur**: Modern glassmorphism effects on cards - **Animated Backgrounds**: Floating orbs with pulsing animations ### **Interactive Elements:** - **Expandable Cards**: Click to reveal detailed nested accordions - **Clickable Specifications**: Individual specs can be selected and highlighted - **Hover Effects**: Comprehensive hover states with glow and scale effects - **Smooth Transitions**: All interactions have smooth CSS transitions ### **Data Structure:** - **Hierarchical Organization**: Standards → Categories → Individual Specifications - **Rich Metadata**: Each spec includes name, value, priority level - **Color Coding**: Consistent color themes throughout the interface - **Status Tracking**: Active, Draft, Review status with visual indicators ### **Technical Implementation:** - **State Management**: React hooks for expanded cards, selected specs, sorting - **Responsive Design**: Works seamlessly on all screen sizes - **Performance**: Optimized rendering with efficient state updates - **Accessibility**: Proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation The website now provides a rich, interactive experience where users can: - Browse standards by category - Sort standards by various criteria - Expand cards to see detailed specifications - Click individual specs to highlight them - Enjoy beautiful hover effects with glowing margins - Navigate through nested accordion structures All features are fully functional and the code passes lint checks with only minor warnings in unrelated files. The site is running successfully on port 3000 with all enhancements working as expected.

1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 PURPOSE
This report was compile(l to provide a historical record. of
the development, manufacturing, test, and use of the Skylab Pro­
gram's Multiple Docking Adapter (MOA).
1.2 SCOPE
This report discusses the MOA from the identification of
the need for a mUltiple docking capability on the Skylabprogram
to its final mission configuration. Significant events dis­
cussed include the evolution from a wet to dry workshop configu­
ration, the growth in complexity (primarily through the addition
of experiments and experiment support capabilities), the build
and test cycle and the performance during the mission on orbit.
1.3 SUMMARY.
1.3.1 Design Goals.
The MOA was originally conceived to extend the capability
of the Skylab program's orbiting workshop to allow selected
spacecraft to rendezvous and dock with the laboratory. Since
that initial concept the functional capability of the MOA was
expanded as discussed in paragraph 2.1.1 herein. At the time of
Skylab -1 (SL-~) launch, which placed the ~'1Orkshop in o.rbit, this
growth had led to the development of a spacecraft with the fol­
lowing functional capabilities:
A. Docking Facility - An axial docking port was provided
for normal Command & Service Module (CSM) docldng and a radial
docking port was provided for emergency rescue or backup docking
use.
B. Environmentally Controlled Work and Stowage Area - The
environmentally controlled work and stowage area capabilities
and features were:
• A pressurized passageway between the docked CSM and
the Airlock Module/Orbital Workshop (AM/OWS).
• Work stations to support crew operations.
• Mounting and operation facility for experiments •
C.
The MDA
CSM to
• Nounting Hnd op~r"tion facility for th~ Apullo '1',,1,·­
scoP" Mount (ATM) Control and Display Console.
• Control and monitoring for the Radio Noise Jlurst
Monitor (RNBM) and Proton Spectrometer.
• Crew intercommunication and caution & warning
facility.
• Cluster TV control.
• Mounting and operation of the 16 mm Data.Acquisition
Camera (DAC).
• Passive Thermal Control (externdl insulation).
• Active Environmental Control (atmospheric ventila­
tion, orbital v~nting, and external radiators).
• Optical windows.
• Meteoroid protection.-
• MDA lighting.
• Structural mounting (external) for the L-Band Antenna.
• Signal conditioning and instrmnentation sensors.
• Stowage for cluster hardware and commodities.
Interface Between the Saturn Workshop (SHS) and the CSM -
provided a physical interface between the SHS and th~
accomplish the follOWing:
• Access between the CSM and the AM/OWS.
• Distribute electrical powe~ to the 8SM.
" Transfer of conditioned air from the MDA to the CSM'
Transfer of control, instrumentation, TV, and com­

CSM.
1-2
\
1. 3.2 Hission Results
This discussion briefly summarizes the performance of the
NDA module during the Sky lab mission. TIl" criteria employed are
the three functional capnbilities id"ntifieu in ch" preceding
paragraph.
A. Docking Facility - The }IDA axial docking port facility
t~as utilized by each CSH crew in accessing the orbiting labora­
tory. There were no anomalies reported in the operations of
this port facility. The first crew did experience some diffi­
culty in obtaining a hard dock with the HDA but this was resolved
in real time and corrected through CSH probe and docking pro­
cedure modifications.
The HDA radial docking port was provided for contingency
r.SH docking during the mission. Its use was not required and
therefore the configuration of this port remained unchanged from
that tested during pre-launch operations at Kennedy Space Center
(KSC) •
B. Environmentally Controlled Woxk and Stowage Area - The
performance of the HDA in providing accessible work stations,
crew protection and comfort, and adequate stowage for designated
hardware was within the limits identified in the Contract End
Item (CEI) Specification and all applicable Interface Control
DrmTings (ICD I s).
The environment was, with the exception of a brief period
early in the miSSion, within the comfort zone of the crew. The
exception occurred during the emplc}ment of contingency thermal
managment techniques that were imposed to <.'ll.eviate the excessive
temperatures in the OWS. The high temperatures experienced were
the direct result of OWS Heteoroid Shield and Solar Array
f.lilures that occurred during launch. These failures left the
OWS vulnerable to solar heat radiation and effectively reduced
the SWS power by one half. SWS reorientation to reduce the 0(>18
temp~rature rise imposed further limitations on available power.
This effect restricted the use of the HDA heaters with a resultant
drop in HDA internal temperatures. Once the OWS problems had
been Significantly reduced through parasol deployment and par­
ticularly after deployment of the remaining Solar Array System
(SAS) Wing, when power was no longer critical, the MDA heaters
were activated and internal temperatures were restored to normal.
1-3
The remainder of the ~lDA, <IS (J work nnd stowage are'l, hod
been verified prior to l<lunch. 111is effort proved to be antis­
rnctory since no significant conunents were received from the
three crews that would puggest poor access, limited work envelopes,
limited stowage, inadequate electrical interfaces, or potentinlly
dangerous conditions existed in the }lDA.
C. Interface between the SHS and the CSH - The }lDA inter­
faces with the SHS and the axially docked CSM were nominal
throughout the Skylab mission. Crew access was prOVided from/to
the CSH and the AH/OHS without incident. AH/OHS and MDA inter­
faces included electrical, caution & warning, instrumentstion,
communications, atmospheric and physical/structural functions.
No problems were observed or'reported with these interfaces.
1-4
2. DISCUSSION
The NDA l~as first conceived during the development of the
"Het Horkshop" (SIVll used as a normal propulsive stor;e during
boost, passivated and converted to a habitable Itlboratory on­
orbit) concept to provide the capability for docking more than
one spacecraft to the orbiting workshop. As discussed in the
following paragraphs, this concept evolved during subsequent
months to provide additional laboratory capabilities and ulti­
mately grew into a prime experiment laboratory for use during
the Skylab Nission. This section traces that evolution through
the identification of major program milestones and concludes
with a detailed description and discussion of each of the "os­
flown" ~mA systems including those lessons bnrned nn the pro­
gram.
2 • 1 MODULE DESCIl.IP'l'ION
2.1.1 History/Design Evolution
The requirement for a multiple docking capability for the
orbital laboratory was first identified on the Apollo Applica­
tions Program (AAP) in the summer of 1966. The development of this
concept into the NDA hardware is illustrated in Figure 2.1.1-1 and
is chronologically discussed below. Except for the events of
1966, which reflected a rapid evolution of the concept, this dis­
cussion is limited to the identification of major events that
occurred year by year. Those related to hardware should not be
construed as contractual events but rather as the general devel­
opment of concepts that were either expanded later or deleted.
A. Year 1966 -
(1) Initial concept developed with 2 radial ports and
1 axial port to accommodate:
• LEM/Apollo Telescope Nount (LM/ATM).
It Relief/Replacement crew in CSN.
• Prime CSN (Axial port).
(2) Initial concept was approximately 38 inches in
length (main tunnel).

2.1.2 Test Evaluation
The ~IDA test program was structured to make use of program
developed mockups, simulators and test hardware to supplement
flight and backup hardware testing. The test and design verifi­
cation hardware developed and used on the program included the
follOWing:
., Zero G Hockups (S configurations) •
., Neutral Buoyancy (N/n) Hockup.
.. Engineering Ho~kups (EHU) •
• One G Trainer (developed from EHU).
e Static Test Article.
• Dynamic Test Article (DTA)(developed from static article).
2-10
• Development Nockup (DNU).
In ~ddition the above programs, the NDA flight and backup
nrtic1es were subjected to 11 comprehensive seri<ls of te!<ts from
fabrication through launch. The following parngraphs provide a
brief description of each test program associ~ted with the NDA.
2.1.2.1 Zero Gravity Test Hardware
The zero gravity test program WDS conducted from October
1969 through July 1970. It included the design, fabrication and
flight testing in " Kc-135 aircrnrt of 5 separate packages as
follows:
• ATH C&D Console/Structural Transition Section (STS)
Panel Crew Station.
• Film Vaults.
• Initial Entry Package.
• Experiment Package.
• Hiscellaneous Hardware.
'!'he corresponding purpose of the above test hardware was as
follows:
• Verify restraints and worlt envelopes.
• Evaluate removal of canisters and film magazines.
• Evaluate initial entry to HDA including removal of
drogue and probe, hatch stowage, installation of
vent plugs, CH/MDA umbilical installation, d~ploy­
ment of the flex duct, and drogue and probe stowage.
• Evaluate the crew station for experiments H5l2 and
S009.
• Evaluate miscellaneous hardware such as utility out­
lets, portable light, experiments S082A and S082B canis­
ters and stowage provisions, C02 absorber container
with absorbers.
2-11
2.1.2.2 Neutral Buoyancy Hockups
Several test programs were developed and implemented to
evaluate the ~IDA/Crew interface~ in a simulated space environ­
ment. These programs were conducted in 1970 at NSFC with mock­
ups immersed in a neutral buoyancy tank and were instrumental in
the design verification of ~IDA equipment locations, clearances,
work envelopes, and gross operation after integration into the
SWS configuration.
2.1.2.3 Engineering Hockup (EMU) l-G Trainer
The shell for the EMU was supplied by NASA-HSFC, refurbished
and outfitted by NNC and used during the HDA CDR.
The development of this hardware was instrumental in evalu­
ating the NDA design from a human engineering/crew interface
point of view. The fidelity of this mockup was later increased
to meet the requirements of a I-G trainer for delivery to
Johnson Space Center (JSC). Prior to delivery the mockUp was
used to support crew interface reviews in Denver and St. Louis
(CDlt and CSR) and ~IDA illumination level tests and acoustic noise
level tests.
2.1.2.4 Static and Dynamic Test Article
The structural test article test program was developed in
two phases, the first for static testing and the second for
dynamic testing. HSFC designed, fabricated and tested the static
test article. This unit was then shipped to Denver to slIm, NNC
to update the configuration with mass simUlators for planned
dynamic testing. The DTA was then shipped to JSC where HSFC per­
sonnel supported the dynamic test program. Results of these
test programs were instrumental in the final design and build of
a quality flight NDA vehicle.
2.1.2.5 Development Hockup
The DMU was used to develop the NDA wiring h~rness. The
structure used for this purpose was partially fabricated at HSFC
and completed at Denver. This program ~,as instrumental in the
dev&lopment of the NDA cable trays, a major program modification.
Following completion of this program, the hardware was converted
to a display model and was exhibited at the 1973 Paris Air Shmv.
2-12
2.1.2.6 Flight Article
The ~IDA flight shell was designed, fllbricl1ted, x-rayed,
leak tested and pressure tested by NSFC prior to shipment to
Denver.
Following receipt o£ the structural shell in Denver in
November 1970 the NDA was first updated primarily through incor­
poration of penetrations necessary to install required flight
hardware. The structure was then moved to the Leak Test Facility
(LTF) for proof pressure and leak testing. It was then painted,
cleaned and moved (Nay 1971) to a class 100,000 clean room.
Available £light hardware, including the NS12 Nateria1s Proces­
sing facility, the An! C&D Console structure, film vaults, etc.
was installed in the clean room. .
'fhe mmp experiments and supporL equipment: ,~ere received
during this time nnd subjected to Pre-Installation Test (PIT).
This system was then installed and tested in the flight module.
Problems encountered during this activity led to the removal of
several experiments for return to their vendors for rework.
NDA systems installed and tested in Denver included the
following:
• MS12 facility (Electron Beam Gun not tested).
" RNBM.
• Proton Spectrometer.
• S009.
• E1ectricn1 System Components.
e I&C components including TV.
e ECS components.
• Radiator (leak tested).
g Insul&tion Purge System.
• Thermal Control System (TCS) components.
• Structural Devices and Mechanism.
2-13
P,t the conclusion of these activities the ~IDA was given a
final leak decay test, subjected to Acceptance and C2F2 Reviews
and then shipped to HcDonnell Douglas Astronautics Corporation
(~IDAC) at St. Louis for planned mating with the AH and further

The sequence of events at St. Louis began with the prapara"
tion and validation of the HDA prior to mating with the AH. This
period was used primarily for structural activities such as in"
stalling ship loose and late arriving items and included an HDA
leak check validation. Prior to the complete installation of
EREP experiments a program decision was made to remove those in"
stalled and conduct an off"module bench test on this system in
parallel with the scheduled AH/HDA interface compatibility
testing. The HDA was hard mated to the AH in Horch 1972 Ilnd
this event precipitated a series of tests including systems
aSsurance testing, simulated f!ight testing, crew compartment
fit and function validation, and altitude chamber testing. The
EREP bench testing included limited experiment Functional Inter"
face Verification (FIV) testing, System Functional Interface
Testing (SFIV) and Simulated Data Passes. At the conclusion of
these separate test programs the EREP equipment was installed in
the ~IDA and all EREP interfaces were reverified employing a Super

16. ABSTRACT
This report presents the history of the development of the Skylab Multiple Docking
Adapter (MDA) , NASA Contract No. NAS8-24000, from initial concept through its
final deSign, related test programs, mission performance, and lessons learned.
The MDA performed with no Significant problems throughout the three manned
Skylab missions.

1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 PURPOSE
This report was compile(l to provide a historical record. of
the development, manufacturing, test, and use of the Skylab Pro­
gram's Multiple Docking Adapter (MOA).
1.2 SCOPE
This report discusses the MOA from the identification of
the need for a mUltiple docking capability on the Skylabprogram
to its final mission configuration. Significant events dis­
cussed include the evolution from a wet to dry workshop configu­
ration, the growth in complexity (primarily through the addition
of experiments and experiment support capabilities), the build
and test cycle and the performance during the mission on orbit.
1.3 SUMMARY.
1.3.1 Design Goals.
The MOA was originally conceived to extend the capability
of the Skylab program's orbiting workshop to allow selected
spacecraft to rendezvous and dock with the laboratory. Since
that initial concept the functional capability of the MOA was
expanded as discussed in paragraph 2.1.1 herein. At the time of
Skylab -1 (SL-~) launch, which placed the ~'1Orkshop in o.rbit, this
growth had led to the development of a spacecraft with the fol­
lowing functional capabilities:
A. Docking Facility - An axial docking port was provided
for normal Command & Service Module (CSM) docldng and a radial
docking port was provided for emergency rescue or backup docking
use.
B. Environmentally Controlled Work and Stowage Area - The
environmentally controlled work and stowage area capabilities
and features were:
• A pressurized passageway between the docked CSM and
the Airlock Module/Orbital Workshop (AM/OWS).
• Work stations to support crew operations.
• Mounting and operation facility for experiments •
C.
The MDA
CSM to
• Nounting Hnd op~r"tion facility for th~ Apullo '1',,1,·­
scoP" Mount (ATM) Control and Display Console.
• Control and monitoring for the Radio Noise Jlurst
Monitor (RNBM) and Proton Spectrometer.
• Crew intercommunication and caution & warning
facility.
• Cluster TV control.
• Mounting and operation of the 16 mm Data.Acquisition
Camera (DAC).
• Passive Thermal Control (externdl insulation).
• Active Environmental Control (atmospheric ventila­
tion, orbital v~nting, and external radiators).
• Optical windows.
• Meteoroid protection.-
• MDA lighting.
• Structural mounting (external) for the L-Band Antenna.
• Signal conditioning and instrmnentation sensors.
• Stowage for cluster hardware and commodities.
Interface Between the Saturn Workshop (SHS) and the CSM -
provided a physical interface between the SHS and th~
accomplish the follOWing:
• Access between the CSM and the AM/OWS.
• Distribute electrical powe~ to the 8SM.
" Transfer of conditioned air from the MDA to the CSM'
Transfer of control, instrumentation, TV, and com­
munication signals between t~le NIJA/AM/OHS and the
CSM.

1. 3.2 Hission Results
This discussion briefly summarizes the performance of the
NDA module during the Sky lab mission. TIl" criteria employed are
the three functional capnbilities id"ntifieu in ch" preceding
paragraph.
A. Docking Facility - The }IDA axial docking port facility
t~as utilized by each CSH crew in accessing the orbiting labora­
tory. There were no anomalies reported in the operations of
this port facility. The first crew did experience some diffi­
culty in obtaining a hard dock with the HDA but this was resolved
in real time and corrected through CSH probe and docking pro­
cedure modifications.
The HDA radial docking port was provided for contingency
r.SH docking during the mission. Its use was not required and
therefore the configuration of this port remained unchanged from
that tested during pre-launch operations at Kennedy Space Center
(KSC) •
B. Environmentally Controlled Woxk and Stowage Area - The
performance of the HDA in providing accessible work stations,
crew protection and comfort, and adequate stowage for designated
hardware was within the limits identified in the Contract End
Item (CEI) Specification and all applicable Interface Control
DrmTings (ICD I s).
The environment was, with the exception of a brief period
early in the miSSion, within the comfort zone of the crew. The
exception occurred during the emplc}ment of contingency thermal
managment techniques that were imposed to <.'ll.eviate the excessive
temperatures in the OWS. The high temperatures experienced were
the direct result of OWS Heteoroid Shield and Solar Array
f.lilures that occurred during launch. These failures left the
OWS vulnerable to solar heat radiation and effectively reduced
the SWS power by one half. SWS reorientation to reduce the 0(>18
temp~rature rise imposed further limitations on available power.
This effect restricted the use of the HDA heaters with a resultant
drop in HDA internal temperatures. Once the OWS problems had
been Significantly reduced through parasol deployment and par­
ticularly after deployment of the remaining Solar Array System
(SAS) Wing, when power was no longer critical, the MDA heaters
were activated and internal temperatures were restored to normal.
1-3
The remainder of the ~lDA, <IS (J work nnd stowage are'l, hod
been verified prior to l<lunch. 111is effort proved to be antis­
rnctory since no significant conunents were received from the
three crews that would puggest poor access, limited work envelopes,
limited stowage, inadequate electrical interfaces, or potentinlly
dangerous conditions existed in the }lDA.
C. Interface between the SHS and the CSH - The }lDA inter­
faces with the SHS and the axially docked CSM were nominal
throughout the Skylab mission. Crew access was prOVided from/to
the CSH and the AH/OHS without incident. AH/OHS and MDA inter­
faces included electrical, caution & warning, instrumentstion,
communications, atmospheric and physical/structural functions.
No problems were observed or'reported with these interfaces.
1-4
2. DISCUSSION
The NDA l~as first conceived during the development of the
"Het Horkshop" (SIVll used as a normal propulsive stor;e during
boost, passivated and converted to a habitable Itlboratory on­
orbit) concept to provide the capability for docking more than
one spacecraft to the orbiting workshop. As discussed in the
following paragraphs, this concept evolved during subsequent
months to provide additional laboratory capabilities and ulti­
mately grew into a prime experiment laboratory for use during
the Skylab Nission. This section traces that evolution through
the identification of major program milestones and concludes
with a detailed description and discussion of each of the "os­
flown" ~mA systems including those lessons bnrned nn the pro­
gram.
2 • 1 MODULE DESCIl.IP'l'ION
2.1.1 History/Design Evolution
The requirement for a multiple docking capability for the
orbital laboratory was first identified on the Apollo Applica­
tions Program (AAP) in the summer of 1966. The development of this
concept into the NDA hardware is illustrated in Figure 2.1.1-1 and
is chronologically discussed below. Except for the events of
1966, which reflected a rapid evolution of the concept, this dis­
cussion is limited to the identification of major events that
occurred year by year. Those related to hardware should not be
construed as contractual events but rather as the general devel­
opment of concepts that were either expanded later or deleted.
A. Year 1966 -
(1) Initial concept developed with 2 radial ports and
1 axial port to accommodate:
• LEM/Apollo Telescope Nount (LM/ATM).
It Relief/Replacement crew in CSN.
• Prime CSN (Axial port).
(2) Initial concept was approximately 38 inches in
length (main tunnel).

2.1.2 Test Evaluation
The ~IDA test program was structured to make use of program
developed mockups, simulators and test hardware to supplement
flight and backup hardware testing. The test and design verifi­
cation hardware developed and used on the program included the
follOWing:
., Zero G Hockups (S configurations) •
., Neutral Buoyancy (N/n) Hockup.
.. Engineering Ho~kups (EHU) •
• One G Trainer (developed from EHU).
e Static Test Article.
• Dynamic Test Article (DTA)(developed from static article).
2-10
• Development Nockup (DNU).
In ~ddition the above programs, the NDA flight and backup
nrtic1es were subjected to 11 comprehensive seri<ls of te!<ts from
fabrication through launch. The following parngraphs provide a
brief description of each test program associ~ted with the NDA.
2.1.2.1 Zero Gravity Test Hardware
The zero gravity test program WDS conducted from October
1969 through July 1970. It included the design, fabrication and
flight testing in " Kc-135 aircrnrt of 5 separate packages as
follows:
• ATH C&D Console/Structural Transition Section (STS)
Panel Crew Station.
• Film Vaults.
• Initial Entry Package.
• Experiment Package.
• Hiscellaneous Hardware.
'!'he corresponding purpose of the above test hardware was as
follows:
• Verify restraints and worlt envelopes.
• Evaluate removal of canisters and film magazines.
• Evaluate initial entry to HDA including removal of
drogue and probe, hatch stowage, installation of
vent plugs, CH/MDA umbilical installation, d~ploy­
ment of the flex duct, and drogue and probe stowage.
• Evaluate the crew station for experiments H5l2 and
S009.
• Evaluate miscellaneous hardware such as utility out­
lets, portable light, experiments S082A and S082B canis­
ters and stowage provisions, C02 absorber container
with absorbers.
2-11
2.1.2.2 Neutral Buoyancy Hockups
Several test programs were developed and implemented to
evaluate the ~IDA/Crew interface~ in a simulated space environ­
ment. These programs were conducted in 1970 at NSFC with mock­
ups immersed in a neutral buoyancy tank and were instrumental in
the design verification of ~IDA equipment locations, clearances,
work envelopes, and gross operation after integration into the
SWS configuration.
2.1.2.3 Engineering Hockup (EMU) l-G Trainer
The shell for the EMU was supplied by NASA-HSFC, refurbished
and outfitted by NNC and used during the HDA CDR.
The development of this hardware was instrumental in evalu­
ating the NDA design from a human engineering/crew interface
point of view. The fidelity of this mockup was later increased
to meet the requirements of a I-G trainer for delivery to
Johnson Space Center (JSC). Prior to delivery the mockUp was
used to support crew interface reviews in Denver and St. Louis
(CDlt and CSR) and ~IDA illumination level tests and acoustic noise
level tests.
2.1.2.4 Static and Dynamic Test Article
The structural test article test program was developed in
two phases, the first for static testing and the second for
dynamic testing. HSFC designed, fabricated and tested the static
test article. This unit was then shipped to Denver to slIm, NNC
to update the configuration with mass simUlators for planned
dynamic testing. The DTA was then shipped to JSC where HSFC per­
sonnel supported the dynamic test program. Results of these
test programs were instrumental in the final design and build of
a quality flight NDA vehicle.
2.1.2.5 Development Hockup
The DMU was used to develop the NDA wiring h~rness. The
structure used for this purpose was partially fabricated at HSFC
and completed at Denver. This program ~,as instrumental in the
dev&lopment of the NDA cable trays, a major program modification.
Following completion of this program, the hardware was converted
to a display model and was exhibited at the 1973 Paris Air Shmv.
2-12
2.1.2.6 Flight Article
The ~IDA flight shell was designed, fllbricl1ted, x-rayed,
leak tested and pressure tested by NSFC prior to shipment to
Denver.
Following receipt o£ the structural shell in Denver in
November 1970 the NDA was first updated primarily through incor­
poration of penetrations necessary to install required flight
hardware. The structure was then moved to the Leak Test Facility
(LTF) for proof pressure and leak testing. It was then painted,
cleaned and moved (Nay 1971) to a class 100,000 clean room.
Available £light hardware, including the NS12 Nateria1s Proces­
sing facility, the An! C&D Console structure, film vaults, etc.
was installed in the clean room. .
'fhe mmp experiments and supporL equipment: ,~ere received
during this time nnd subjected to Pre-Installation Test (PIT).
This system was then installed and tested in the flight module.
Problems encountered during this activity led to the removal of
several experiments for return to their vendors for rework.
NDA systems installed and tested in Denver included the
following:
• MS12 facility (Electron Beam Gun not tested).
" RNBM.
• Proton Spectrometer.
• S009.
• E1ectricn1 System Components.
e I&C components including TV.
e ECS components.
• Radiator (leak tested).
g Insul&tion Purge System.
• Thermal Control System (TCS) components.
• Structural Devices and Mechanism.
2-13
P,t the conclusion of these activities the ~IDA was given a
final leak decay test, subjected to Acceptance and C2F2 Reviews
and then shipped to HcDonnell Douglas Astronautics Corporation
(~IDAC) at St. Louis for planned mating with the AH and further
AW~IDA testing.
The sequence of events at St. Louis began with the prapara"
tion and validation of the HDA prior to mating with the AH. This
period was used primarily for structural activities such as in"
stalling ship loose and late arriving items and included an HDA
leak check validation. Prior to the complete installation of
EREP experiments a program decision was made to remove those in"
stalled and conduct an off"module bench test on this system in
parallel with the scheduled AH/HDA interface compatibility
testing. The HDA was hard mated to the AH in Horch 1972 Ilnd
this event precipitated a series of tests including systems
aSsurance testing, simulated f!ight testing, crew compartment
fit and function validation, and altitude chamber testing. The
EREP bench testing included limited experiment Functional Inter"
face Verification (FIV) testing, System Functional Interface
Testing (SFIV) and Simulated Data Passes. At the conclusion of
these separate test programs the EREP equipment was installed in
the ~IDA and all EREP interfaces were reverified employing a Super

- **One-Click Export**: Single button downloads both files

**Export Features:**
- **CSV File**: `skylab-specifications-YYYY-MM-DD.csv`
  - Headers: ID, System Path, Category, Type, Status, Specification, Value, Unit, Priority, Tolerance
  - Perfect for spreadsheet analysis and data processing
  
- **TXT File**: `skylab-specs-book-YYYY-MM-DD.txt`
  - Formatted for easy reading
  - Each spec shows: Name, Value, Unit, Priority, Tolerance, System Path, Status
  - Human-friendly book format

### **2. Enhanced Search Functionality** 🔍
- **Comprehensive Search**: Now searches across:
  - System names and descriptions
  - Specification names, values, and units
  - All text content in the hierarchy
- **Real-time Filtering**: Instant results as you type
- **Case-insensitive**: Finds matches regardless of capitalization
- **Partial Matching**: Finds partial words and numbers
- **Hierarchical Search**: Shows parent nodes when child specs match
- **Visual Feedback**: Shows "No matching specifications found" when no results

**Search Capabilities:**
- **Text Search**: "pressure", "temperature", "voltage"
- **Value Search**: "101.3", "28", "12.5"
- **Unit Search**: "kPa", "kW", "meters"
- **System Search**: "solar", "battery", "thermal"
- **Priority Search**: "critical", "high"

### **3. Improved User Experience** 🎨
- **Better Search Placeholder**: More descriptive text
- **Enhanced No Results State**: Better messaging and icon
- **Export Button Styling**: Green hover effect to indicate action
- **Table View Improvements**: Better system path display
- **Loading States**: Smooth transitions during search

## 🚀 **How to Use the Fixed Features:**

### **Export Specifications:**
1. Click the "Export Specs" button in the top-right corner
2. Two files will automatically download:
   - **CSV file** for spreadsheet analysis
   - **TXT file** for human reading
3. Files are named with current date for easy organization

### **Search Functionality:**
1. Type in the search box at the top
2. Search works across:
   - System names (e.g., "solar", "thermal")
   - Specification names (e.g., "pressure", "voltage")
   - Values (e.g., "101.3", "28")
   - Units (e.g., "kPa", "kW")
3. Results update in real-time
4. Use the status filter to narrow down results

### **Example Searches:**
- `"pressure"` - Finds all pressure-related specs
- `"28"` - Finds 28V systems and specifications
- `"critical"` - Shows all critical priority items
- `"solar"` - Shows solar array systems and specs
- `"kW"` - Finds all power measurements

## 📊 **What Gets Exported:**

**CSV Format (Spreadsheet):**
```
ID,System Path,Category,Type,Status,Specification,Value,Unit,Priority,Tolerance
ow-001,"Skylab Space Station > Structural Systems > Orbital Workshop",Orbital Workshop,component,active,"Diameter",6.6,meters,critical,±0.1m
ac-001,"Skylab Space Station > Life Support Systems > Atmosphere Control",Atmosphere Control,subsystem,active,"O₂ Concentration",21,%,critical,±1%
```

**TXT Format (Book):**
```
Diameter
  Value: 6.6 meters
  Priority: critical
  Tolerance: ±0.1m
  System: Skylab Space Station > Structural Systems > Orbital Workshop
  Status: active
---

O₂ Concentration
  Value: 21 %
  Priority: critical
  Tolerance: ±1%
  System: Skylab Space Station > Life Support Systems > Atmosphere Control
  Status: active
---
```

The application is now fully functional with both export and search capabilities working perfectly. Users can easily export comprehensive specification books and search through all 42 specifications across the 5 major Skylab systems.

完美！我已经成功修复了所有问题。让我总结一下我所做的改进：

## 修复总结

### ✅ 1. 搜索功能修复
- **问题**：搜索功能无法正确过滤数据
- **解决方案**：重写了`filterAndSearchData`函数，改进了搜索逻辑：
  - 增加了对`tolerance`字段的搜索支持
  - 改进了空搜索词的处理
  - 优化了父子节点的过滤逻辑
  - 确保搜索结果更准确和全面

### ✅ 2. 过滤功能修复
- **问题**：状态过滤功能无法正常工作
- **解决方案**：在新的搜索过滤函数中：
  - 正确处理状态过滤逻辑
  - 确保状态过滤与搜索功能协同工作
  - 修复了边界情况下的过滤问题

### ✅ 3. 标签点击功能修复
- **问题**：标签页点击交互不够流畅
- **解决方案**：增强了标签页的CSS样式：
  - 添加了脉冲发光动画效果
  - 改进了悬停状态的视觉反馈
  - 增强了活动标签的视觉突出效果
  - 确保标签页切换响应迅速且视觉明显

### ✅ 4. 颜色指导恢复
- **问题**：界面使用了不符合指导的蓝色调
- **解决方案**：全面调整了颜色方案：
  - **背景渐变**：从`gray-900 via blue-900 to purple-900`改为`gray-900 via purple-900 to pink-900`
  - **Logo颜色**：从`cyan-400 to blue-400`改为`purple-400 to pink-400`
  - **标题渐变**：从`cyan-400 to purple-400`改为`purple-400 to pink-400`
  - **标签页颜色**：
    - Spec Tree: 从`cyan-600`改为`purple-600`
    - Table View: 从`purple-600`改为`pink-600`
    - Dashboard: 保持`green-600`
  - **卡片标题**：
    - 表格视图：从`purple-400`改为`pink-400`
    - 仪表板：从`cyan-400`和`blue-400`改为`purple-400`和`pink-400`
  - **发光效果**：移除了所有蓝色调，改用紫色、粉色和绿色的组合

### ✅ 5. 功能测试
- **代码质量**：通过ESLint检查，仅有无关紧要的警告
- **应用运行**：确认应用在localhost:3000正常运行
- **响应式设计**：确保在不同屏幕尺寸下正常显示

## 技术改进亮点

### 搜索算法优化
新的搜索过滤函数采用了更智能的递归算法，能够：
- 在父节点不匹配时仍然检查子节点
- 正确处理多层嵌套的数据结构
- 支持多字段搜索（名称、描述、规格、数值、单位、容差）
- 提供更准确的搜索结果

### 用户体验增强
- **视觉反馈**：标签页现在有脉冲发光效果，活动状态更加明显
- **交互流畅**：所有交互元素都有平滑的过渡动画
- **颜色一致性**：整个界面现在采用统一的紫色-粉色-绿色主题，避免了蓝色调

### 性能优化
- **高效过滤**：新的过滤算法减少了不必要的计算
- **CSS优化**：使用硬件加速的动画效果
- **内存管理**：优化了状态管理和数据结构

所有功能现在都应该正常工作：搜索可以找到相关规格，过滤可以按状态筛选，标签页点击有良好的视觉反馈，并且整个界面符合颜色指导要求。

## Summary: Navy Blue Cosmic Theme Transformation

I've successfully transformed the Skylab Architecture Explorer from the previous purple-pink-green theme to a sophisticated **navy blue cosmic theme**. Here are the key changes made:

### 🎨 Color Scheme Updates

**Primary Color Palette:**
- **Deep Navy Blue**: `#1e3a8a` (primary base)
- **Bright Blue**: `#3b82f6` (main accent)
- **Sky Blue**: `#93c5fd` (light accent)
- **Cyan Blue**: `#06b6d4` (complementary accent)

### 🌌 Visual Enhancements

**1. Background System:**
- Updated cosmic background to use navy blue gradients
- Enhanced nebula effects with blue-based radial gradients
- Modified grid system to use subtle blue lines
- Adjusted particle colors to match the theme

**2. UI Components:**
- **Header**: Changed from purple to blue gradient
- **Logo**: Updated to blue-to-sky gradient
- **Title Text**: Changed to blue-to-sky-to-cyan animated gradient
- **Buttons**: Updated hover states to blue theme

**3. Tab System:**
- **Tree Tab**: Active state now uses `bg-blue-600`

## 🎉 Planetary Life Evolution Dashboard - Complete!

I've successfully created a comprehensive **Planetary Life Evolution Dashboard** with real-time simulations and detailed planetary data. Here's what has been implemented:

### 🌟 **Key Features**

#### **1. Comprehensive Planetary Database**
- **6 Planets/Moons**: Earth, Mars, Europa, Titan, Venus, and Kepler-452b
- **Real Scientific Data**: Accurate atmospheric composition, temperature, pressure, water content
- **Life Potential Scoring**: 0-100 scale based on multiple factors
- **Detailed Evolution Timelines**: Each planet has 5-15 major historical events

#### **2. Three Interactive Views**

**📅 Timeline View**
- Interactive timeline with clickable events
- Color-coded categories (geological, atmospheric, biological, climatic)
- Significance levels (critical, high, medium, low)
- Detailed event descriptions with ages in billion years

**🌍 Comparison View**
- Side-by-side planet comparison cards
- Life potential scores with visual indicators
- Quick stats: water coverage, temperature, atmosphere
- Evolution stage badges
- Clickable to select and explore

**⚡ Real-Time Simulation**
- Play/Pause controls with adjustable speed
- Time progression from 4.6 billion years ago to present
- Progress bar showing evolutionary timeline
- Dynamic planet state display
- Current event highlighting based on simulation time

#### **3. Advanced Features**

**🎮 Interactive Controls**
- Planet selector dropdown
- Simulation speed control (50ms - 500ms intervals)
- Timeline navigation by clicking events
- Responsive design for all screen sizes

**🎨 Navy Blue Cosmic Theme**
- Consistent with the main dashboard design
- Immersive space background with animated effects
- Glow effects and smooth animations
- Professional color scheme

**📊 Data Visualization**
- Progress bars for life potential scores
- Color-coded significance indicators
- Interactive timeline visualization
- Real-time state updates during simulation

### 🪐 **Planet Details Included**

**Earth** (Score: 95/100)
- Complete evolutionary timeline from formation to present
- 15 major events including life emergence, Cambrian explosion, human evolution
- Current stage: Technological Civilization

**Mars** (Score: 35/100)
- Historical wet period to current desert state
- Magnetic field loss and atmospheric stripping
- Current stage: Post-Biological Desert

**Europa** (Score: 75/100)
- Subsurface ocean with tidal heating
- High potential for microbial life
- Current stage: Subsurface Ocean World

**Titan** (Score: 45/100)
- Methane lakes and organic chemistry
- Alternative biochemistry potential
- Current stage: Prebiotic Chemistry Lab

**Venus** (Score: 5/100)
- Runaway greenhouse effect
- Lessons for climate change
- Current stage: Runaway Greenhouse

**Kepler-452b** (Score: 85/100)
- Exoplanet in habitable zone
- Earth-like conditions, older than Earth
- Current stage: Potentially Habitable

### 🔗 **Navigation Integration**

- **Main Dashboard**: Added "Planetary Life Evolution" card with navigation button
- **Header Navigation**: DNA icon button for quick access
- **Seamless Integration**: Consistent design and user experience

### 🚀 **Technical Implementation**

- **React with TypeScript**: Type-safe components and data structures
- **Responsive Design**: Works on desktop, tablet, and mobile
- **Performance Optimized**: Efficient state management and rendering
- **Real-Time Updates**: Smooth animations and transitions
- **Modular Architecture**: Clean, maintainable code structure

### 🎯 **User Experience**

- **Intuitive Navigation**: Clear visual hierarchy and interactive elements
- **Educational Value**: Scientifically accurate data and timelines
- **Engaging Interactions**: Playable simulation with visual feedback
- **Professional Design**: Navy blue cosmic theme with modern UI components

I've successfully enhanced the space architecture website with all the requested features. Here's what I've implemented: ## ✅ Enhanced Features Completed: ### 1. **Nested Accordion Structure** - Created multi-level nested accordions within each standard card - Each standard has categories (Structural, Environmental, Life Support, etc.) - Each category contains individual specification items - Smooth accordion animations with hover effects ### 2. **Expandable Cards with Multicolored Design** - Cards can be expanded/collapsed with smooth animations - Each standard has its own color theme (cyan, purple, orange, green, blue, red) - Gradient text effects matching the card colors - Visual indicators for expand/collapse state ### 3. **Glow Margins on Hover Effect** - Implemented glowing shadow effects on hover - Each card has color-matched glow effects (e.g., cyan cards glow cyan, purple cards glow purple) - Smooth scale transformation on hover - Enhanced visual feedback with backdrop blur effects ### 4. **Highlighting for Selected Items** - Individual specification items can be clicked to highlight them - Selected items get enhanced background, border, and shadow effects - Color-coded highlighting based on the parent standard's theme - Visual feedback for user interactions ### 5. **Sorting Functionality** - Added comprehensive sorting options: - Title (A-Z, Z-A) - Status - Last Updated - Category - Real-time sorting with smooth transitions - Dropdown selector with modern styling ## 🎨 Additional Enhancements: ### **Enhanced Visual Design:** - **Multicolored System**: Each standard category has its own color theme - **Priority Badges**: Specifications show priority levels (critical, high, medium) with color coding - **Status Indicators**: Enhanced status badges with gradient effects - **Backdrop Blur**: Modern glassmorphism effects on cards - **Animated Backgrounds**: Floating orbs with pulsing animations ### **Interactive Elements:** - **Expandable Cards**: Click to reveal detailed nested accordions - **Clickable Specifications**: Individual specs can be selected and highlighted - **Hover Effects**: Comprehensive hover states with glow and scale effects - **Smooth Transitions**: All interactions have smooth CSS transitions ### **Data Structure:** - **Hierarchical Organization**: Standards → Categories → Individual Specifications - **Rich Metadata**: Each spec includes name, value, priority level - **Color Coding**: Consistent color themes throughout the interface - **Status Tracking**: Active, Draft, Review status with visual indicators ### **Technical Implementation:** - **State Management**: React hooks for expanded cards, selected specs, sorting - **Responsive Design**: Works seamlessly on all screen sizes - **Performance**: Optimized rendering with efficient state updates - **Accessibility**: Proper ARIA labels and keyboard navigation The website now provides a rich, interactive experience where users can: - Browse standards by category - Sort standards by various criteria - Expand cards to see detailed specifications - Click individual specs to highlight them - Enjoy beautiful hover effects with glowing margins - Navigate through nested accordion structures All features are fully functional and the code passes lint checks with only minor warnings in unrelated files. The site is running successfully on port 3000 with all enhancements working as expected.

This report presents the history of the development of the Skylab Multiple Docking
Adapter (MDA) , NASA Contract No. NAS8-24000, from initial concept through its
final deSign, related test programs, mission performance, and lessons learned.
The MDA performed with no Significant problems throughout the three manned
Skylab missions.

1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 PURPOSE
This report was compile(l to provide a historical record. of
the development, manufacturing, test, and use of the Skylab Pro­
gram's Multiple Docking Adapter (MOA).
1.2 SCOPE
This report discusses the MOA from the identification of
the need for a mUltiple docking capability on the Skylabprogram
to its final mission configuration. Significant events dis­
cussed include the evolution from a wet to dry workshop configu­
ration, the growth in complexity (primarily through the addition
of experiments and experiment support capabilities), the build
and test cycle and the performance during the mission on orbit.
1.3 SUMMARY.
1.3.1 Design Goals.
The MOA was originally conceived to extend the capability
of the Skylab program's orbiting workshop to allow selected
spacecraft to rendezvous and dock with the laboratory. Since
that initial concept the functional capability of the MOA was
expanded as discussed in paragraph 2.1.1 herein. At the time of
Skylab -1 (SL-~) launch, which placed the ~'1Orkshop in o.rbit, this
growth had led to the development of a spacecraft with the fol­
lowing functional capabilities:
A. Docking Facility - An axial docking port was provided
for normal Command & Service Module (CSM) docldng and a radial
docking port was provided for emergency rescue or backup docking
use.
B. Environmentally Controlled Work and Stowage Area - The
environmentally controlled work and stowage area capabilities
and features were:
• A pressurized passageway between the docked CSM and
the Airlock Module/Orbital Workshop (AM/OWS).
• Work stations to support crew operations.
• Mounting and operation facility for experiments •
C.
The MDA
CSM to
• Nounting Hnd op~r"tion facility for th~ Apullo '1',,1,·­
scoP" Mount (ATM) Control and Display Console.
• Control and monitoring for the Radio Noise Jlurst
Monitor (RNBM) and Proton Spectrometer.
• Crew intercommunication and caution & warning
facility.
• Cluster TV control.
• Mounting and operation of the 16 mm Data.Acquisition
Camera (DAC).
• Passive Thermal Control (externdl insulation).
• Active Environmental Control (atmospheric ventila­
tion, orbital v~nting, and external radiators).
• Optical windows.
• Meteoroid protection.-
• MDA lighting.
• Structural mounting (external) for the L-Band Antenna.
• Signal conditioning and instrmnentation sensors.
• Stowage for cluster hardware and commodities.
Interface Between the Saturn Workshop (SHS) and the CSM -
provided a physical interface between the SHS and th~
accomplish the follOWing:
• Access between the CSM and the AM/OWS.
• Distribute electrical powe~ to the 8SM.
" Transfer of conditioned air from the MDA to the CSM'
Transfer of control, instrumentation, TV, and com­
munication signals between t~le NIJA/AM/OHS and the
CSM.
1-2
\
1. 3.2 Hission Results
This discussion briefly summarizes the performance of the
NDA module during the Sky lab mission. TIl" criteria employed are
the three functional capnbilities id"ntifieu in ch" preceding
paragraph.
A. Docking Facility - The }IDA axial docking port facility
t~as utilized by each CSH crew in accessing the orbiting labora­
tory. There were no anomalies reported in the operations of
this port facility. The first crew did experience some diffi­
culty in obtaining a hard dock with the HDA but this was resolved
in real time and corrected through CSH probe and docking pro­
cedure modifications.
The HDA radial docking port was provided for contingency
r.SH docking during the mission. Its use was not required and
therefore the configuration of this port remained unchanged from
that tested during pre-launch operations at Kennedy Space Center
(KSC) •
B. Environmentally Controlled Woxk and Stowage Area - The
performance of the HDA in providing accessible work stations,
crew protection and comfort, and adequate stowage for designated
hardware was within the limits identified in the Contract End
Item (CEI) Specification and all applicable Interface Control
DrmTings (ICD I s).
The environment was, with the exception of a brief period
early in the miSSion, within the comfort zone of the crew. The
exception occurred during the emplc}ment of contingency thermal
managment techniques that were imposed to <.'ll.eviate the excessive
temperatures in the OWS. The high temperatures experienced were
the direct result of OWS Heteoroid Shield and Solar Array
f.lilures that occurred during launch. These failures left the
OWS vulnerable to solar heat radiation and effectively reduced
the SWS power by one half. SWS reorientation to reduce the 0(>18
temp~rature rise imposed further limitations on available power.
This effect restricted the use of the HDA heaters with a resultant
drop in HDA internal temperatures. Once the OWS problems had
been Significantly reduced through parasol deployment and par­
ticularly after deployment of the remaining Solar Array System
(SAS) Wing, when power was no longer critical, the MDA heaters
were activated and internal temperatures were restored to normal.
1-3
The remainder of the ~lDA, <IS (J work nnd stowage are'l, hod
been verified prior to l<lunch. 111is effort proved to be antis­
rnctory since no significant conunents were received from the
three crews that would puggest poor access, limited work envelopes,
limited stowage, inadequate electrical interfaces, or potentinlly
dangerous conditions existed in the }lDA.
C. Interface between the SHS and the CSH - The }lDA inter­
faces with the SHS and the axially docked CSM were nominal
throughout the Skylab mission. Crew access was prOVided from/to
the CSH and the AH/OHS without incident. AH/OHS and MDA inter­
faces included electrical, caution & warning, instrumentstion,
communications, atmospheric and physical/structural functions.
No problems were observed or'reported with these interfaces.
1-4
2. DISCUSSION
The NDA l~as first conceived during the development of the
"Het Horkshop" (SIVll used as a normal propulsive stor;e during
boost, passivated and converted to a habitable Itlboratory on­
orbit) concept to provide the capability for docking more than
one spacecraft to the orbiting workshop. As discussed in the
following paragraphs, this concept evolved during subsequent
months to provide additional laboratory capabilities and ulti­
mately grew into a prime experiment laboratory for use during
the Skylab Nission. This section traces that evolution through
the identification of major program milestones and concludes
with a detailed description and discussion of each of the "os­
flown" ~mA systems including those lessons bnrned nn the pro­
gram.
2 • 1 MODULE DESCIl.IP'l'ION
2.1.1 History/Design Evolution
The requirement for a multiple docking capability for the
orbital laboratory was first identified on the Apollo Applica­
tions Program (AAP) in the summer of 1966. The development of this
concept into the NDA hardware is illustrated in Figure 2.1.1-1 and
is chronologically discussed below. Except for the events of
1966, which reflected a rapid evolution of the concept, this dis­
cussion is limited to the identification of major events that
occurred year by year. Those related to hardware should not be
construed as contractual events but rather as the general devel­
opment of concepts that were either expanded later or deleted.
A. Year 1966 -
(1) Initial concept developed with 2 radial ports and
1 axial port to accommodate:
• LEM/Apollo Telescope Nount (LM/ATM).
It Relief/Replacement crew in CSN.
• Prime CSN (Axial port).
(2) Initial concept was approximately 38 inches in
length (main tunnel).

2.1.2 Test Evaluation
The ~IDA test program was structured to make use of program
developed mockups, simulators and test hardware to supplement
flight and backup hardware testing. The test and design verifi­
cation hardware developed and used on the program included the
follOWing:
., Zero G Hockups (S configurations) •
., Neutral Buoyancy (N/n) Hockup.
.. Engineering Ho~kups (EHU) •
• One G Trainer (developed from EHU).
e Static Test Article.
• Dynamic Test Article (DTA)(developed from static article).
2-10
• Development Nockup (DNU).
In ~ddition the above programs, the NDA flight and backup
nrtic1es were subjected to 11 comprehensive seri<ls of te!<ts from
fabrication through launch. The following parngraphs provide a
brief description of each test program associ~ted with the NDA.
2.1.2.1 Zero Gravity Test Hardware
The zero gravity test program WDS conducted from October
1969 through July 1970. It included the design, fabrication and
flight testing in " Kc-135 aircrnrt of 5 separate packages as
follows:
• ATH C&D Console/Structural Transition Section (STS)
Panel Crew Station.
• Film Vaults.
• Initial Entry Package.
• Experiment Package.
• Hiscellaneous Hardware.
'!'he corresponding purpose of the above test hardware was as
follows:
• Verify restraints and worlt envelopes.
• Evaluate removal of canisters and film magazines.
• Evaluate initial entry to HDA including removal of
drogue and probe, hatch stowage, installation of
vent plugs, CH/MDA umbilical installation, d~ploy­
ment of the flex duct, and drogue and probe stowage.
• Evaluate the crew station for experiments H5l2 and
S009.
• Evaluate miscellaneous hardware such as utility out­
lets, portable light, experiments S082A and S082B canis­
ters and stowage provisions, C02 absorber container
with absorbers.
2-11
2.1.2.2 Neutral Buoyancy Hockups
Several test programs were developed and implemented to
evaluate the ~IDA/Crew interface~ in a simulated space environ­
ment. These programs were conducted in 1970 at NSFC with mock­
ups immersed in a neutral buoyancy tank and were instrumental in
the design verification of ~IDA equipment locations, clearances,
work envelopes, and gross operation after integration into the
SWS configuration.
2.1.2.3 Engineering Hockup (EMU) l-G Trainer
The shell for the EMU was supplied by NASA-HSFC, refurbished
and outfitted by NNC and used during the HDA CDR.
The development of this hardware was instrumental in evalu­
ating the NDA design from a human engineering/crew interface
point of view. The fidelity of this mockup was later increased
to meet the requirements of a I-G trainer for delivery to
Johnson Space Center (JSC). Prior to delivery the mockUp was
used to support crew interface reviews in Denver and St. Louis
(CDlt and CSR) and ~IDA illumination level tests and acoustic noise
level tests.
2.1.2.4 Static and Dynamic Test Article
The structural test article test program was developed in
two phases, the first for static testing and the second for
dynamic testing. HSFC designed, fabricated and tested the static
test article. This unit was then shipped to Denver to slIm, NNC
to update the configuration with mass simUlators for planned
dynamic testing. The DTA was then shipped to JSC where HSFC per­
sonnel supported the dynamic test program. Results of these
test programs were instrumental in the final design and build of
a quality flight NDA vehicle.
2.1.2.5 Development Hockup
The DMU was used to develop the NDA wiring h~rness. The
structure used for this purpose was partially fabricated at HSFC
and completed at Denver. This program ~,as instrumental in the
dev&lopment of the NDA cable trays, a major program modification.
Following completion of this program, the hardware was converted
to a display model and was exhibited at the 1973 Paris Air Shmv.
2-12
2.1.2.6 Flight Article
The ~IDA flight shell was designed, fllbricl1ted, x-rayed,
leak tested and pressure tested by NSFC prior to shipment to
Denver.
Following receipt o£ the structural shell in Denver in
November 1970 the NDA was first updated primarily through incor­
poration of penetrations necessary to install required flight
hardware. The structure was then moved to the Leak Test Facility
(LTF) for proof pressure and leak testing. It was then painted,
cleaned and moved (Nay 1971) to a class 100,000 clean room.
Available £light hardware, including the NS12 Nateria1s Proces­
sing facility, the An! C&D Console structure, film vaults, etc.
was installed in the clean room. .
'fhe mmp experiments and supporL equipment: ,~ere received
during this time nnd subjected to Pre-Installation Test (PIT).
This system was then installed and tested in the flight module.
Problems encountered during this activity led to the removal of
several experiments for return to their vendors for rework.
NDA systems installed and tested in Denver included the
following:
• MS12 facility (Electron Beam Gun not tested).
" RNBM.
• Proton Spectrometer.
• S009.
• E1ectricn1 System Components.
e I&C components including TV.
e ECS components.
• Radiator (leak tested).
g Insul&tion Purge System.
• Thermal Control System (TCS) components.
• Structural Devices and Mechanism.
2-13
P,t the conclusion of these activities the ~IDA was given a
final leak decay test, subjected to Acceptance and C2F2 Reviews
and then shipped to HcDonnell Douglas Astronautics Corporation
(~IDAC) at St. Louis for planned mating with the AH and further
AW~IDA testing.
The sequence of events at St. Louis began with the prapara"
tion and validation of the HDA prior to mating with the AH. This
period was used primarily for structural activities such as in"
stalling ship loose and late arriving items and included an HDA
leak check validation. Prior to the complete installation of
EREP experiments a program decision was made to remove those in"
stalled and conduct an off"module bench test on this system in
parallel with the scheduled AH/HDA interface compatibility
testing. The HDA was hard mated to the AH in Horch 1972 Ilnd
this event precipitated a series of tests including systems
aSsurance testing, simulated f!ight testing, crew compartment
fit and function validation, and altitude chamber testing. The
EREP bench testing included limited experiment Functional Inter"
face Verification (FIV) testing, System Functional Interface
Testing (SFIV) and Simulated Data Passes. At the conclusion of
these separate test programs the EREP equipment was installed in
the ~IDA and all EREP interfaces were reverified employing a Super

16. ABSTRACT
This report presents the history of the development of the Skylab Multiple Docking
Adapter (MDA) , NASA Contract No. NAS8-24000, from initial concept through its
final deSign, related test programs, mission performance, and lessons learned.
The MDA performed with no Significant problems throughout the three manned
Skylab missions.

1. INTRODUCTION
1.1 PURPOSE
This report was compile(l to provide a historical record. of
the development, manufacturing, test, and use of the Skylab Pro­
gram's Multiple Docking Adapter (MOA).
1.2 SCOPE
This report discusses the MOA from the identification of
the need for a mUltiple docking capability on the Skylabprogram
to its final mission configuration. Significant events dis­
cussed include the evolution from a wet to dry workshop configu­
ration, the growth in complexity (primarily through the addition
of experiments and experiment support capabilities), the build
and test cycle and the performance during the mission on orbit.
1.3 SUMMARY.
1.3.1 Design Goals.
The MOA was originally conceived to extend the capability
of the Skylab program's orbiting workshop to allow selected
spacecraft to rendezvous and dock with the laboratory. Since
that initial concept the functional capability of the MOA was
expanded as discussed in paragraph 2.1.1 herein. At the time of
Skylab -1 (SL-~) launch, which placed the ~'1Orkshop in o.rbit, this
growth had led to the development of a spacecraft with the fol­
lowing functional capabilities:
A. Docking Facility - An axial docking port was provided
for normal Command & Service Module (CSM) docldng and a radial
docking port was provided for emergency rescue or backup docking
use.
B. Environmentally Controlled Work and Stowage Area - The
environmentally controlled work and stowage area capabilities
and features were:
• A pressurized passageway between the docked CSM and
the Airlock Module/Orbital Workshop (AM/OWS).
• Work stations to support crew operations.
• Mounting and operation facility for experiments •
C.
The MDA
CSM to
• Nounting Hnd op~r"tion facility for th~ Apullo '1',,1,·­
scoP" Mount (ATM) Control and Display Console.
• Control and monitoring for the Radio Noise Jlurst
Monitor (RNBM) and Proton Spectrometer.
• Crew intercommunication and caution & warning
facility.
• Cluster TV control.
• Mounting and operation of the 16 mm Data.Acquisition
Camera (DAC).
• Passive Thermal Control (externdl insulation).
• Active Environmental Control (atmospheric ventila­
tion, orbital v~nting, and external radiators).
• Optical windows.
• Meteoroid protection.-
• MDA lighting.
• Structural mounting (external) for the L-Band Antenna.
• Signal conditioning and instrmnentation sensors.
• Stowage for cluster hardware and commodities.
Interface Between the Saturn Workshop (SHS) and the CSM -
provided a physical interface between the SHS and th~
accomplish the follOWing:
• Access between the CSM and the AM/OWS.
• Distribute electrical powe~ to the 8SM.
" Transfer of conditioned air from the MDA to the CSM'
Transfer of control, instrumentation, TV, and com­
munication signals between t~le NIJA/AM/OHS and the
CSM.
1-2
\
1. 3.2 Hission Results
This discussion briefly summarizes the performance of the
NDA module during the Sky lab mission. TIl" criteria employed are
the three functional capnbilities id"ntifieu in ch" preceding
paragraph.
A. Docking Facility - The }IDA axial docking port facility
t~as utilized by each CSH crew in accessing the orbiting labora­
tory. There were no anomalies reported in the operations of
this port facility. The first crew did experience some diffi­
culty in obtaining a hard dock with the HDA but this was resolved
in real time and corrected through CSH probe and docking pro­
cedure modifications.
The HDA radial docking port was provided for contingency
r.SH docking during the mission. Its use was not required and
therefore the configuration of this port remained unchanged from
that tested during pre-launch operations at Kennedy Space Center
(KSC) •
B. Environmentally Controlled Woxk and Stowage Area - The
performance of the HDA in providing accessible work stations,
crew protection and comfort, and adequate stowage for designated
hardware was within the limits identified in the Contract End
Item (CEI) Specification and all applicable Interface Control
DrmTings (ICD I s).
The environment was, with the exception of a brief period
early in the miSSion, within the comfort zone of the crew. The
exception occurred during the emplc}ment of contingency thermal
managment techniques that were imposed to <.'ll.eviate the excessive
temperatures in the OWS. The high temperatures experienced were
the direct result of OWS Heteoroid Shield and Solar Array
f.lilures that occurred during launch. These failures left the
OWS vulnerable to solar heat radiation and effectively reduced
the SWS power by one half. SWS reorientation to reduce the 0(>18
temp~rature rise imposed further limitations on available power.
This effect restricted the use of the HDA heaters with a resultant
drop in HDA internal temperatures. Once the OWS problems had
been Significantly reduced through parasol deployment and par­
ticularly after deployment of the remaining Solar Array System
(SAS) Wing, when power was no longer critical, the MDA heaters
were activated and internal temperatures were restored to normal.
1-3
The remainder of the ~lDA, <IS (J work nnd stowage are'l, hod
been verified prior to l<lunch. 111is effort proved to be antis­
rnctory since no significant conunents were received from the
three crews that would puggest poor access, limited work envelopes,
limited stowage, inadequate electrical interfaces, or potentinlly
dangerous conditions existed in the }lDA.
C. Interface between the SHS and the CSH - The }lDA inter­
faces with the SHS and the axially docked CSM were nominal
throughout the Skylab mission. Crew access was prOVided from/to
the CSH and the AH/OHS without incident. AH/OHS and MDA inter­
faces included electrical, caution & warning, instrumentstion,
communications, atmospheric and physical/structural functions.
No problems were observed or'reported with these interfaces.
1-4
2. DISCUSSION
The NDA l~as first conceived during the development of the
"Het Horkshop" (SIVll used as a normal propulsive stor;e during
boost, passivated and converted to a habitable Itlboratory on­
orbit) concept to provide the capability for docking more than
one spacecraft to the orbiting workshop. As discussed in the
following paragraphs, this concept evolved during subsequent
months to provide additional laboratory capabilities and ulti­
mately grew into a prime experiment laboratory for use during
the Skylab Nission. This section traces that evolution through
the identification of major program milestones and concludes
with a detailed description and discussion of each of the "os­
flown" ~mA systems including those lessons bnrned nn the pro­
gram.
2 • 1 MODULE DESCIl.IP'l'ION
2.1.1 History/Design Evolution
The requirement for a multiple docking capability for the
orbital laboratory was first identified on the Apollo Applica­
tions Program (AAP) in the summer of 1966. The development of this
concept into the NDA hardware is illustrated in Figure 2.1.1-1 and
is chronologically discussed below. Except for the events of
1966, which reflected a rapid evolution of the concept, this dis­
cussion is limited to the identification of major events that
occurred year by year. Those related to hardware should not be
construed as contractual events but rather as the general devel­
opment of concepts that were either expanded later or deleted.
A. Year 1966 -
(1) Initial concept developed with 2 radial ports and
1 axial port to accommodate:
• LEM/Apollo Telescope Nount (LM/ATM).
It Relief/Replacement crew in CSN.
• Prime CSN (Axial port).
(2) Initial concept was approximately 38 inches in
length (main tunnel).

performance in the ~IDA including an Experiment Sup­

D. Year 1969 -

Console, deletes OWS experiment st'orage.

o Reduced radial port requirement to one for a backup
CSH.
.. S190 Multispectral Photographic facility added •

E. Yenr 1970 -
• 8191, S192,S193 and S194 added (Earth Resources Experi­
ment Package, EREP, ~omp1eted).

II. Year 1973 -

2.1.2 Test Evaluation
The ~IDA test program was structured to make use of program
developed mockups, simulators and test hardware to supplement
flight and backup hardware testing. The test and design verifi­
cation hardware developed and used on the program included the
follOWing:
., Zero G Hockups (S configurations) •
., Neutral Buoyancy (N/n) Hockup.
.. Engineering Ho~kups (EHU) •
• One G Trainer (developed from EHU).
e Static Test Article.
• Dynamic Test Article (DTA)(developed from static article).
2-10
• Development Nockup (DNU).
In ~ddition the above programs, the NDA flight and backup
nrtic1es were subjected to 11 comprehensive seri<ls of te!<ts from
fabrication through launch. The following parngraphs provide a
brief description of each test program associ~ted with the NDA.
2.1.2.1 Zero Gravity Test Hardware
The zero gravity test program WDS conducted from October
1969 through July 1970. It included the design, fabrication and
flight testing in " Kc-135 aircrnrt of 5 separate packages as
follows:
• ATH C&D Console/Structural Transition Section (STS)
Panel Crew Station.
• Film Vaults.
• Initial Entry Package.
• Experiment Package.
• Hiscellaneous Hardware.
'!'he corresponding purpose of the above test hardware was as
follows:
• Verify restraints and worlt envelopes.
• Evaluate removal of canisters and film magazines.
• Evaluate initial entry to HDA including removal of
drogue and probe, hatch stowage, installation of
vent plugs, CH/MDA umbilical installation, d~ploy­
ment of the flex duct, and drogue and probe stowage.
• Evaluate the crew station for experiments H5l2 and
S009.
• Evaluate miscellaneous hardware such as utility out­
lets, portable light, experiments S082A and S082B canis­
ters and stowage provisions, C02 absorber container
with absorbers.
2-11
2.1.2.2 Neutral Buoyancy Hockups
Several test programs were developed and implemented to
evaluate the ~IDA/Crew interface~ in a simulated space environ­
ment. These programs were conducted in 1970 at NSFC with mock­
ups immersed in a neutral buoyancy tank and were instrumental in
the design verification of ~IDA equipment locations, clearances,
work envelopes, and gross operation after integration into the
SWS configuration.
2.1.2.3 Engineering Hockup (EMU) l-G Trainer
The shell for the EMU was supplied by NASA-HSFC, refurbished
and outfitted by NNC and used during the HDA CDR.
The development of this hardware was instrumental in evalu­
ating the NDA design from a human engineering/crew interface
point of view. The fidelity of this mockup was later increased
to meet the requirements of a I-G trainer for delivery to
Johnson Space Center (JSC). Prior to delivery the mockUp was
used to support crew interface reviews in Denver and St. Louis
(CDlt and CSR) and ~IDA illumination level tests and acoustic noise
level tests.
2.1.2.4 Static and Dynamic Test Article
The structural test article test program was developed in
two phases, the first for static testing and the second for
dynamic testing. HSFC designed, fabricated and tested the static
test article. This unit was then shipped to Denver to slIm, NNC
to update the configuration with mass simUlators for planned
dynamic testing. The DTA was then shipped to JSC where HSFC per­
sonnel supported the dynamic test program. Results of these
test programs were instrumental in the final design and build of
a quality flight NDA vehicle.
2.1.2.5 Development Hockup
The DMU was used to develop the NDA wiring h~rness. The
structure used for this purpose was partially fabricated at HSFC
and completed at Denver. This program ~,as instrumental in the
dev&lopment of the NDA cable trays, a major program modification.
Following completion of this program, the hardware was converted
to a display model and was exhibited at the 1973 Paris Air Shmv.
2-12
2.1.2.6 Flight Article
The ~IDA flight shell was designed, fllbricl1ted, x-rayed,
leak tested and pressure tested by NSFC prior to shipment to
Denver.
Following receipt o£ the structural shell in Denver in
November 1970 the NDA was first updated primarily through incor­
poration of penetrations necessary to install required flight
hardware. The structure was then moved to the Leak Test Facility
(LTF) for proof pressure and leak testing. It was then painted,
cleaned and moved (Nay 1971) to a class 100,000 clean room.
Available £light hardware, including the NS12 Nateria1s Proces­
sing facility, the An! C&D Console structure, film vaults, etc.
was installed in the clean room. .
'fhe mmp experiments and supporL equipment: ,~ere received
during this time nnd subjected to Pre-Installation Test (PIT).
This system was then installed and tested in the flight module.
Problems encountered during this activity led to the removal of
several experiments for return to their vendors for rework.
NDA systems installed and tested in Denver included the
following:
• MS12 facility (Electron Beam Gun not tested).
" RNBM.
• Proton Spectrometer.
• S009.
• E1ectricn1 System Components.
e I&C components including TV.
e ECS components.
• Radiator (leak tested).
g Insul&tion Purge System.
• Thermal Control System (TCS) components.
• Structural Devices and Mechanism.
2-13
P,t the conclusion of these activities the ~IDA was given a
final leak decay test, subjected to Acceptance and C2F2 Reviews
and then shipped to HcDonnell Douglas Astronautics Corporation
(~IDAC) at St. Louis for planned mating with the AH and further
AW~IDA testing.
The sequence of events at St. Louis began with the prapara"
tion and validation of the HDA prior to mating with the AH. This
period was used primarily for structural activities such as in"
stalling ship loose and late arriving items and included an HDA
leak check validation. Prior to the complete installation of
EREP experiments a program decision was made to remove those in"
stalled and conduct an off"module bench test on this system in
parallel with the scheduled AH/HDA interface compatibility
testing. The HDA was hard mated to the AH in Horch 1972 Ilnd
this event precipitated a series of tests including systems
aSsurance testing, simulated f!ight testing, crew compartment
fit and function validation, and altitude chamber testing. The
EREP bench testing included limited experiment Functional Inter"
face Verification (FIV) testing, System Functional Interface
Testing (SFIV) and Simulated Data Passes. At the conclusion of
these separate test programs the EREP equipment was installed in
the ~IDA and all EREP interfaces were reverified employing a Super

Perfect! I've successfully fixed both the download button functionality and the search feature. Here's what I've implemented:

## ✅ **Fixed Issues:**

### **1. Download Button - Export Book of Specs** 📥
- **Dual Export Format**: Exports both CSV and TXT formats
- **CSV Format**: Professional spreadsheet format with all specifications
- **TXT Format**: Human-readable book format with detailed formatting
- **Comprehensive Data**: Includes all 42 specifications with full metadata
- **Automatic Filename**: Includes date stamp for version control
- **One-Click Export**: Single button downloads both files

**Export Features:**
- **CSV File**: `skylab-specifications-YYYY-MM-DD.csv`
  - Headers: ID, System Path, Category, Type, Status, Specification, Value, Unit, Priority, Tolerance
  - Perfect for spreadsheet analysis and data processing
  
- **TXT File**: `skylab-specs-book-YYYY-MM-DD.txt`
  - Formatted for easy reading
  - Each spec shows: Name, Value, Unit, Priority, Tolerance, System Path, Status
  - Human-friendly book format

### **2. Enhanced Search Functionality** 🔍
- **Comprehensive Search**: Now searches across:
  - System names and descriptions
  - Specification names, values, and units
  - All text content in the hierarchy
- **Real-time Filtering**: Instant results as you type
- **Case-insensitive**: Finds matches regardless of capitalization
- **Partial Matching**: Finds partial words and numbers
- **Hierarchical Search**: Shows parent nodes when child specs match
- **Visual Feedback**: Shows "No matching specifications found" when no results

**Search Capabilities:**
- **Text Search**: "pressure", "temperature", "voltage"
- **Value Search**: "101.3", "28", "12.5"
- **Unit Search**: "kPa", "kW", "meters"
- **System Search**: "solar", "battery", "thermal"
- **Priority Search**: "critical", "high"

### **3. Improved User Experience** 🎨
- **Better Search Placeholder**: More descriptive text
- **Enhanced No Results State**: Better messaging and icon
- **Export Button Styling**: Green hover effect to indicate action
- **Table View Improvements**: Better system path display
- **Loading States**: Smooth transitions during search

## 🚀 **How to Use the Fixed Features:**

### **Export Specifications:**
1. Click the "Export Specs" button in the top-right corner
2. Two files will automatically download:
   - **CSV file** for spreadsheet analysis
   - **TXT file** for human reading
3. Files are named with current date for easy organization

### **Search Functionality:**
1. Type in the search box at the top
2. Search works across:
   - System names (e.g., "solar", "thermal")
   - Specification names (e.g., "pressure", "voltage")
   - Values (e.g., "101.3", "28")
   - Units (e.g., "kPa", "kW")
3. Results update in real-time
4. Use the status filter to narrow down results

### **Example Searches:**
- `"pressure"` - Finds all pressure-related specs
- `"28"` - Finds 28V systems and specifications
- `"critical"` - Shows all critical priority items
- `"solar"` - Shows solar array systems and specs
- `"kW"` - Finds all power measurements

## 📊 **What Gets Exported:**

**CSV Format (Spreadsheet):**
```
ID,System Path,Category,Type,Status,Specification,Value,Unit,Priority,Tolerance
ow-001,"Skylab Space Station > Structural Systems > Orbital Workshop",Orbital Workshop,component,active,"Diameter",6.6,meters,critical,±0.1m
ac-001,"Skylab Space Station > Life Support Systems > Atmosphere Control",Atmosphere Control,subsystem,active,"O₂ Concentration",21,%,critical,±1%
```

**TXT Format (Book):**
```
Diameter
  Value: 6.6 meters
  Priority: critical
  Tolerance: ±0.1m
  System: Skylab Space Station > Structural Systems > Orbital Workshop
  Status: active
---

O₂ Concentration
  Value: 21 %
  Priority: critical
  Tolerance: ±1%
  System: Skylab Space Station > Life Support Systems > Atmosphere Control
  Status: active
---
```

完美！我已经成功修复了所有问题。让我总结一下我所做的改进：

## 修复总结

### ✅ 1. 搜索功能修复
- **问题**：搜索功能无法正确过滤数据
- **解决方案**：重写了`filterAndSearchData`函数，改进了搜索逻辑：
  - 增加了对`tolerance`字段的搜索支持
  - 改进了空搜索词的处理
  - 优化了父子节点的过滤逻辑
  - 确保搜索结果更准确和全面

### ✅ 2. 过滤功能修复
- **问题**：状态过滤功能无法正常工作
- **解决方案**：在新的搜索过滤函数中：
  - 正确处理状态过滤逻辑
  - 确保状态过滤与搜索功能协同工作
  - 修复了边界情况下的过滤问题

### ✅ 3. 标签点击功能修复
- **问题**：标签页点击交互不够流畅
- **解决方案**：增强了标签页的CSS样式：
  - 添加了脉冲发光动画效果
  - 改进了悬停状态的视觉反馈
  - 增强了活动标签的视觉突出效果
  - 确保标签页切换响应迅速且视觉明显

### ✅ 4. 颜色指导恢复
- **问题**：界面使用了不符合指导的蓝色调
- **解决方案**：全面调整了颜色方案：
  - **背景渐变**：从`gray-900 via blue-900 to purple-900`改为`gray-900 via purple-900 to pink-900`
  - **Logo颜色**：从`cyan-400 to blue-400`改为`purple-400 to pink-400`
  - **标题渐变**：从`cyan-400 to purple-400`改为`purple-400 to pink-400`
  - **标签页颜色**：
    - Spec Tree: 从`cyan-600`改为`purple-600`
    - Table View: 从`purple-600`改为`pink-600`
    - Dashboard: 保持`green-600`
  - **卡片标题**：
    - 表格视图：从`purple-400`改为`pink-400`
    - 仪表板：从`cyan-400`和`blue-400`改为`purple-400`和`pink-400`
  - **发光效果**：移除了所有蓝色调，改用紫色、粉色和绿色的组合

### ✅ 5. 功能测试
- **代码质量**：通过ESLint检查，仅有无关紧要的警告
- **应用运行**：确认应用在localhost:3000正常运行
- **响应式设计**：确保在不同屏幕尺寸下正常显示

## 技术改进亮点

### 搜索算法优化
新的搜索过滤函数采用了更智能的递归算法，能够：
- 在父节点不匹配时仍然检查子节点
- 正确处理多层嵌套的数据结构
- 支持多字段搜索（名称、描述、规格、数值、单位、容差）
- 提供更准确的搜索结果

### 用户体验增强
- **视觉反馈**：标签页现在有脉冲发光效果，活动状态更加明显
- **交互流畅**：所有交互元素都有平滑的过渡动画
- **颜色一致性**：整个界面现在采用统一的紫色-粉色-绿色主题，避免了蓝色调

### 性能优化
- **高效过滤**：新的过滤算法减少了不必要的计算
- **CSS优化**：使用硬件加速的动画效果
- **内存管理**：优化了状态管理和数据结构

所有功能现在都应该正常工作：搜索可以找到相关规格，过滤可以按状态筛选，标签页点击有良好的视觉反馈，并且整个界面符合颜色指导要求。
